Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 39023  
November 2005 
 
 
 
Technical Assistance 
Greater Silk Road Initiative 2006

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  CAP  –  comprehensive action plan 
  CAREC  –  Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation 
  MC  –  ministerial conference 
  MI  –  multilateral institutions 
  OIF  –  overall institutional framework 
  RBR  –  regional business roundtable 
  RCSP  –  regional cooperation strategy and program 
  RETA  –  regional technical assistance 
  RM  –  resident mission 
  SCC  –  sectoral coordinating committee 
  SOM  –  senior officials’ meeting 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Targeting Classification  –  General Intervention 
Sector  –  Multisector (Transport and communications, energy, industry and 
trade) 
Subsector  –  Multimodal transport and sector development, energy sector 
development, trade 
Themes  –  Sustainable economic growth, regional cooperation, capacity 
development 
Subthemes  –  Promoting economic efficiency and enabling markets, fostering 
physical infrastructure development, institutional development 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
Vice President   J.B. Eichenberger, Operations Group 2 
Director General  H.S. Rao, East and Central Asia Department 
Director  A.H. Ruthenberg, Operations Coordination Division, East and Central Asia 
Department 
Team Leader  Q. Zhang, Senior Regional Cooperation Programs Specialist, East and 
Central Asia Department

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) Program, initiated by the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) in 1997, has evolved into a multicountry and multi-institutional 
framework  that  comprises  eight  participating  countries  (Afghanistan,1  Azerbaijan,  People’s 
Republic of China, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyz Republic, Mongolia, Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan) and an 
alliance  of  six  multilateral  institutions  (ADB,  European  Bank  for  Reconstruction  and 
Development,  International  Monetary  Fund,  Islamic  Development  Bank,  United  Nations 
Development Programme, and World Bank), with ADB servising as program Secretariat. At the 
core of the Program lies the overall institutional framework (OIF), which consists of (i) an annual 
ministerial conference (MC) that provides overall guidance and makes policy and directional 
decisions, (ii) senior officials’ meeting (SOM) that coordinates on cross-sectoral issues and 
prepares for the ministerial conference, (iii) sectoral coordinating committees (SCCs) at the 
operational level that coordinate sectorwide issues and implementation, and (iv) a national focal 
point in each participating country to ensure effective coordination among government agencies 
and other parties concerned.  
 
2.  At the 4TH MC on CAREC in November 2005, the ministers renewed their commitment to 
regional  cooperation,  reconfirmed  the  basic  principles2  of  the  OIF,  and  agreed  that  the 
processing and implementation of regional initiatives should be accelerated.  
 
3.  ADB adopted in 2004 the CAREC Member Countries Regional Cooperation Strategy 
and Program 2005–2007 (RCSP).3 The RCSP enshrined the establishment in 2002 of the OIF 
as a milestone in the partnership and trust among program participants (footnote 3, para. 72). 
Further  strengthening  of  the  OIF  forms  part  of  ADB’s  expanded  program  for  regional 
cooperation  (footnote  3,  Figure  1,  p.  24),  which  is  critical  to  achieving  the  four  strategic 
objectives of the CAREC Program.4 To this end, the assistance pipeline for nonlending products 
and services as envisaged by the RCSP included the Greater Silk Road Initiative 2006. The 
technical assistance (TA) design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.   As  initiator  of  the  CAREC  Program  and  program  Secretariat,  ADB  approved  from 
October 2000 to June 2005 eleven loans totaling $275.1 million for seven regional investment 
projects, and 23 CAREC-related TA projects totaling $17.4 million. ADB has also leveraged 
cofinancing amounting to $140.7 million for three projects.  
 
5.  In  light  of  ADB’s  policy  paper  on  regional  cooperation,6  the  CAREC  Program  has 
followed a phased approach, which started with background economic analysis and institutions 
assessment,  focused  thereafter  on  identification  and  prefeasibility  analysis  of  investment 
projects, and then expanded to support for policy dialogue and institution development.  
                                                 
1  Afghanistan joined the CAREC Program as a full participant at the CAREC Senior Officials’ Meeting in October 
2005. 
2  Including consensus, pragmatism, and results orientation. 
3  ADB. 2004. Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Member Countries Regional Cooperation Strategy and 
Program (2005–2007). Manila (Doc. IN.158-04). 
4  That is, (i) increasing trade and integration with large markets, both globally and in the region’s proximity; (ii) 
improving economic cooperation within the region to reduce costs of transport and facilitate transit; (iii) improving 
supplies of energy; and (iv) tackling negative externalities. 
5  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities (internet edition) on 17 June 2005. 
6  ADB. 1994. Bank Support for Regional Cooperation. Manila (Doc. R60-94).

2   
6.  Prior to this TA, a number of “umbrella” regional technical assistance (RETAs) were 
approved and implemented for the CAREC Program, including those for the development and 
continuous functioning of its OIF.7 Major lessons learned from these RETAs are the following: (i) 
regional cooperation is a long process that calls for sustained political will and mutual trust; (ii) 
lack of proper understanding of the actual benefits and costs of regional cooperation constitutes 
an obstacle in promoting regional cooperation; (iii) institutional and capacity development is 
urgently required for the success of the regional initiative; and (iv) there is need to show tangible 
and concrete results from key regional projects to further advance regional cooperation.8 At the 
same time, it is also noted that promoting regional cooperation is resource intensive, though in 
the long term the efforts made and costs incurred could be more than compensated by more 
efficient economy of the region, sustained economic growth of the participating countries, and 
higher living standards of their people.  
 
7.  During the period 2004–2005, regional cooperation under the CAREC Program has 
maintained its momentum and made further achievements, including (i) the successful holding 
of the 3RD MC in November 2004 and the 4TH MC in November 2005, where ministers of the 
participating  countries  provided  specific  guidance  on  further  direction  and  activities  of  the 
CAREC Program; (ii) strengthened coordination among the MIs in the CAREC framework; (iii) 
discussion at the SOM in April 2005 and general consensus on a number of key strategic 
questions facing CAREC, including geographic and program scope, treatment of policy agenda, 
positioning  of  CAREC  vis-à-vis  other  regional  initiatives,  effectiveness  and  results-based 
orientation of the Program, and promotion of private sector participation; (iv) progress made in 
all priority areas of the Program; and (v) provision of lending and nonlending assistance to 
support regional cooperation in Central Asia.9  
 
8.  Despite the progress so far, many important challenges that remain or are emerging 
need to be properly addressed if the CAREC Program is to achieve more tangible results: (i) the 
benefits of regional cooperation need to be understood better and by a wider audience; (ii) 
mutual trust among CAREC countries needs to be further enhanced, including at sector and 
working levels where political will and in-principle agreement on regional economic cooperation 
have to be translated into concrete and concerted efforts in implementation; (iii) there is need for 
the  OIF  to  be  further  consolidated  and  results-oriented,  from  which  CAREC  participating 
countries could find sustained enthusiasm and momentum for regional economic cooperation, 
and on which the MIs will continue to set the foundation of their alliance; and (iv) though the 
CAREC  Program  remains  highly  relevant  for  the  participating  countries,  the  development 
assistance community must recognize that regional cooperation in such a politically and socially 
sensitive region as Central Asia requires realistic targets and approaches, and sustained and 
long-term financial support. 
 
9.  In view of the imperative need for regional cooperation and the progress that has been 
made by the CAREC Program, and to overcome difficulties and challenges faced, the CAREC 
participating countries have been calling upon ADB to play a greater role in regional cooperation 
                                                 
7  These include (i) ADB. 2002. Technical Assistance for the Greater Silk Road Initiative. Manila (TA 6053-REG, 
approved in October 2002 with ADB financing totaling $950,000); and (ii) ADB. 2004. Technical Assistance for the 
Greater Silk Road Initiative 2005. Manila (TA 6199-REG, approved in November 2004 with ADB financing totaling 
$900,000). 
8  ADB. 2004. Technical Assistance Completion Report on Regional Economic Cooperation in Central Asia (Phase 
II). Manila (Doc. IN.128-04); and ADB. 2004. Technical Assistance Completion Report on Regional Economic 
Cooperation in Central Asia (Phase II–Year Two). Manila (Doc. IN.235-04). 
9  ADB alone approved in 2004 four loan projects totaling $88.1 million and nine TAs for $4.95 million.

3
in Central Asia. This call points to the need for ADB to continue supporting the OIF of the 
CAREC.  
 
10.  ADB’s TA for the OIF must however be designed and implemented taking into account 
lessons learned from previous TAs (para. 6) and following understanding reached at the most 
recent MCs and SOMs: (i) the OIF of the CAREC Program should continue to operate based on 
the principle of consensus among the participating countries and MIs, retaining its flexibility and 
at the same time its unique identity vis-à-vis other regional programs and institutions; (ii) to more 
effectively use resources and avoid duplication, further coordination/rationalization should be 
explored  and  carried  out  between  the  CAREC  Program  and  other  regional  cooperation 
initiatives including the Central and South Asia Transport and Trade Forum (CSATTF)10 and 
other regional programs for Central Asia espoused by ADB’s major multilateral and bilateral 
development  partners;  (iii)  cooperation  with  key  neighboring  countries  (e.g.  the  Russian 
Federation) is getting more and more important for the continuous success and further advance 
of  the  CAREC  Program;  (iv)  more  analytical  works  and  tangible  results  are  needed  for 
enhancing confidence in and moving forward with regional cooperation in Central Asia; and (v) 
participation of the private sector in CAREC  activities will infuse the Program  with a new 
dimension and revived impetus. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The TA is expected to contribute to economic growth and better living standards in the 
CAREC participating countries through regional economic cooperation. The outcome of the TA 
will be a strengthened OIF for further progress and tangible results of the CAREC Program. The 
outcome will be achieved through the following major outputs: (i) policy and strategic guidance 
provided by the MC and SOMs for further deepening and advancing the CAREC Program; (ii) 
program and analytical works on regional cooperation, including a comprehensive action plan 
(CAP) and performance indicators; (iii) engagement of the private sector with the CAREC 
program; and (iv) dissemination of knowledge and information on CAREC activities.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The TA will focus on strengthening the OIF, which lies at the core of the CAREC 
Program, and on supporting related programming works and analytical studies that will help 
guide the general direction of the CAREC Program. On the other hand, as an umbrella TA for 
the CAREC Program, appropriate flexibility will be applied in implementation to cope with the 
evolving  nature  of  CAREC  and  to  respond  to  the  changing  demands  of  its  participating 
countries. The following key activities that will generate the expected outputs will be funded by 
the TA. 
 
13.  Facilitating and Enhancing Regional Dialogue. ADB has proved to be well-positioned 
to initiate, facilitate, and enhance frank and constructive dialogues on regional cooperation 
among  CAREC  countries,  because  of  its  neutral  status  as  a  multilateral  international 
organization focusing on economic development and poverty reduction, and because it serves 
as program Secretariat. Playing this role entails financial support for preparing and holding 
                                                 
10 CSATTF was established in 2003 at its first Ministerial Conference with a membership of Afghanistan, Iran, 
Pakistan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan to strengthen transport and trade links through improved transit 
corridors of the subregion, which connect Central Asia and South Asia and the ports of the Arabian Sea and the 
Persian Gulf through Afghanistan.

4   
meetings and conferences of the OIF of CAREC, and providing related secretariat services. The 
TA will prepare and support the holding of the 5TH MC in the last quarter of 2006, at least two 
SOMs prior to the 5TH MC, as well as a number of SCC meetings and other pertinent high-level 
forums  under  the  OIF.  The  TA  will  also  support  coordination  between  the  OIF  and  other 
initiatives for regional cooperation in Central Asia, to minimize duplication and secure synergy 
between different initiatives. In connection with the need to coordinate and assist with CAREC-
related  projects  and  to  monitor  other  regional  initiatives  in  the  field,  the  TA  will  fund  one 
domestic consultant/regional cooperation coordinator in each resident mission (RM) of ADB in 
CAREC participating countries.   
 
14.  Conducting Analytical Works and Results-Oriented Planning in Support of the 
OIF. As a regional cooperation platform that is gaining ground and recognition, the CAREC 
Program is bound to expand its activities, with possible broadening of its sector/subsector 
coverage. For that reason, more analytical works11 will be conducted in support of the OIF, for it 
to make well-informed and realistic decisions based on a good grasp of the potential benefits, 
drawbacks,  and  risks  involved  in  the  issues  and  related  options  discussed.  Comparative 
analysis of experience and lessons learned in similar areas from other initiatives for regional 
cooperation, either in Central Asia or elsewhere in the world, will also be useful for the OIF in its 
decision-making process. In addition, as reconfirmed by the 4TH MC in November 2005, it is time 
to set up key performance indicators for the CAREC Program, which should be embodied in a 
CAP. The TA will support analytical and planning works in these areas.   
 
15.  Promoting Private Sector Participation in the CAREC Program. A call for greater 
participation of the private sector in the CAREC Program was made by the CAREC SOM in 
April 2004 and in April 2005. The call envisaged two major thrusts: (i) launching and regular 
convening  of  the  Regional  Business  Roundtable  (RBR);  and  (ii)  development  and 
implementation of the strategy note for CAREC private sector development.  
 
16.  The major objectives of the RBR include (i) enhancing business inputs into CAREC by 
providing direct and regular channels for the private sector to communicate with the participating 
governments on broad issues in the priority areas of the CAREC Program, as well as on specific 
projects and initiatives; (ii) facilitating the development of soft and hard infrastructure for regional 
trade and investment; and (iii) building networks of the business community in the countries 
concerned to encourage cooperation and cofinancing in subregional projects and other related 
regional initiatives. An RBR preparatory meeting was convened in early November 2005, which 
officially launched the RBR that will be held annually starting from 2006.  
 
17.  The strategy note for CAREC private sector development aims at improving the policy, 
legal, and regulatory environment, as well as services in support of private sector development 
in  the  CAREC  economies.  The  major  approach  envisaged  includes  enhancing  the  role  of 
business associations and chambers of commerce in the participating countries. The approach 
entails developing a much greater range of activities to benefit members of the chambers and 
other  related  parties,  and  enhancing  the  role  of  the  chambers  in  reflecting  business 
perspectives in national policy making and in regional economic cooperation.  
  
18.  Enhancing Dissemination of Knowledge and Information on CAREC Activities.  
Over the years, the CAREC Program has generated a wealth of studies and knowledge on 
cross-country issues in Central Asia, particularly in the priority areas of transport, energy, trade 
                                                 
11 Such as the study on the competitiveness of Central Asian states, and a multicountry general equilibrium model 
involving PRC, Mongolia, Russia, and Uzbekistan.

5
policy, and trade facilitation. Furthermore, day-to-day activities under the CAREC framework are 
bringing  about  new  or  additional  knowledge  and  information.  Wider  and  more  systematic 
dissemination of knowledge and information on CAREC activities will help consolidate the OIF 
through reinforced trust in regional cooperation, better understanding of the role assumed and 
works undertaken by CAREC, and larger support from stakeholders. The TA will continue to   
support the revamped CAREC website, and the preparation and circulation of the quarterly 
regional newsletters in addition to Central Asia Regional News Digest. In light of the newly 
approved public communications policy of ADB,12 the TA will support translation of selected key 
reports and studies or their summaries into Russian and Chinese. In consultation with the 
Department of External Relations and the RMs concerned, other means of communications will 
be explored as appropriate for enhancing external outreach and dissemination. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
19.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.05 million equivalent. ADB will finance $985,000 on a 
grant basis from ADB's TA funding program. The participating governments will provide the 
remaining $65,000 equivalent, equal to the imputed value of staff time and use of government 
facilities conducting activities under the TA. Detailed cost estimates are given in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
20.  The TA will be implemented over 15 months, from 1 January 2006 to 31 March 2007. 
ADB will be the Executing Agency. ADB’s CAREC unit in the Operations Coordination Division 
will be responsible for overall implementation of TA activities in light of the guidance and specific 
requirements of the CAREC MCs and SOMs. To ensure effective implementation of the TA, 
there  will  be  close  coordination  with  the  national  focal  point  in  each  CAREC  participating 
country, other MIs in the CAREC framework, SCCs, and ADB’s RMs concerned.  
 
21.  For implementation of this TA, seven person-months of international consulting services 
will be engaged, on an intermittent basis, to assist with analytical works and results-oriented 
planning. In addition, 120 person-months of domestic consulting services will be required for 
coordination, country reporting, knowledge dissemination, and technical support for the CAREC 
Secretariat, including 12 person-months for one regional cooperation coordinator in each RM 
located in the CAREC participating countries. ADB will engage the consultants in accordance 
with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for 
engaging  domestic  consultants.  An  outline  of  the  terms  of  reference  for  consultants  is  in 
Appendix 3. The equipment budgeted under the TA consists of a strictly limited number of 
computers that will be procured in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement and will 
be left with the Executing Agency at the completion of the TA.    
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $985,000 on a grant basis for 
the Greater Silk Road Initiative 2006, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
                                                 
12 ADB. 2005. The Public Communications Policy of the Asian Development Bank: Disclosure and Exchange of 
Information. Manila (R101-05).

10  Appendix 3  
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  A total of 7 person-months international and 120 person-months domestic consulting 
services will be required for the proposed technical assistance (TA). Given that the TA will 
support a range of activities of the Greater Silk Road Initiative under the Central Asia Regional 
Economic Cooperation (CAREC) Program, some of which are still being planned, detailed terms 
of reference for specific tasks may be revised and supplemented at a later stage as appropriate. 
 
1.    Advisor/Regional Cooperation Specialist/Economist (international, 7 person-
months) 
2.  Independent individual consultant(s) will be engaged on an intermittent basis, to do the 
following: 
   
(i)  Perform  analytical  studies  of  regional  cooperation  in  relation  to  further 
strengthening  of  the  overall  institutional  framework  (OIF)  and  to  strategic 
direction  and  possible  deepening  and  broadening  of  the  CAREC  Program, 
including coordination and cooperation with other regional cooperation initiatives 
and multilateral or bilateral aid agencies. 
(ii)  Complete and help implement for the CAREC Program a comprehensive action 
plan (CAP) that embodies key performance indicators. 
(iii)  Perform other analytical studies as required particularly in the priority areas of 
transport, energy, trade policy, and trade facilitation. 
(iv)  Advise on and assist in promoting participation of the private sector and business 
communities in the CAREC Program, including implementing the strategy note 
on  CAREC  private  sector  development  and  instituting  a  regional  business 
roundtable. 
(v)  Assist the head of the CAREC Unit in planning, preparing for, and implementing 
conferences and meetings for the initiative, including the preparation of resource 
papers. 
(vi)  Oversee  improvements  to  the  CAREC  website  and  regional  newsletter,  and 
provide necessary input. 
(vii)  Help coordinate, integrate, and monitor the various TA activities.   
(viii)  Provide  other  technical  and  coordinating  support  to  the  OIF  of  the  CAREC 
Program, as required. 
 
2.  Development Economist (domestic, 12 person-months) 
3.  The development economist will do the following: 
 
(i)  Assist the secretariat to the OIF. 
(ii)  Assist in organizing ministerial conferences, senior officials’ meetings, and other 
meetings  and  workshops;  prepare  resource  papers  for  these  meetings;  and 
perform other follow-up activities. 
(iii)  Prepare quarterly monitoring reports on TA implementation, which covers the 
status of proposed activities under the TA and related activities, and outstanding 
issues and slippages for the attention of the head of the CAREC Unit. 
(iv)  Create, maintain, and upgrade a database for analysis and measurement of 
results and outcomes of the CAREC Program, which covers (a) implementation 
status and updating of the CAREC regional assistance pipeline, (b) activities of 
various regional initiatives, (c) participation of the private sector and business

Appendix 3   11 
community in the CAREC Program, and (d) publications and analytical studies on 
regional cooperation. 
(v)  Help prepare project profiles for regional projects. 
(vi)  Help  implement  the  TA,  including  (a)  monitoring  budget  disbursements, 
consultant recruitment, and contract variations; and (b) procuring other inputs. 
 
3.  In-Country Regional Cooperation Coordinators (domestic, 96 person-months) 
4.  One domestic consultant in each participating country will be engaged for 12 months to 
serve as field coordinator, with the following primary responsibilities: 
 
(i)  Serve as focal point on regional economic cooperation in the developing member 
countries (DMC) concerned, coordinating CAREC-related issues with national 
and sector focal points in the Government, other Government bodies involved in 
regional cooperation activities, representatives of multilateral institution and other 
aid agencies in the field, business communities and other stakeholders, as well 
as the Asian Development Bank (ADB)’s CAREC Unit.  
(ii)  Establish and maintain, through regular, day-to-day contact and consultation, 
long-term working relationships with key government agencies responsible for 
regional economic cooperation. 
(iii)  Ensure implementation of the regional work program in the country. 
(iv)  Undertake  or  provide  inputs  to  CAREC-related  economic  research, 
sector/strategy/thematic studies, and other analytical work, including assistance 
in completing the CAP and monitoring its implementation. 
(v)  Monitor regional projects being implemented by ADB in the country, and assist in 
implementing them, if necessary. 
(vi)  Assist in the logistics and other arrangements for meetings and conferences 
under the OIF, which include sectoral coordinating committee meetings, senior 
officials' meetings, and the ministerial conference. 
(vii)  Prepare regular reports on regional cooperation initiatives and activities in the 
country,  and  provide  inputs  to  the  Central  Asia  Regional  News  Digest,  the 
quarterly CAREC newsletter, and the website. 
(viii)  Monitor programs and initiatives of the Government and regional organizations 
on regional economic cooperation; identify, evaluate, and recommend potential 
areas for ADB assistance. 
(ix)  Monitor programs of other stakeholders, especially of external funding agencies 
operating in the country; identify, evaluate, and recommend potential areas of 
cooperation. 
(x)  Participate in relevant ADB missions and conferences/meetings. 
(xi)  Help identify and develop potential new areas of the initiative. 
(xii)  Report on all activities monthly. 
(xiii)  Perform other regional cooperation and ADB-related tasks as assigned by the 
country director or head of the CAREC Unit. 
 
4.  Experts on Website, Media, and Publication (domestic, 12 person-months) 
5.  Domestic consulting services will be engaged to (i) further improve the CAREC website 
of both content and presentation; (ii) support publication of a quarterly regional newsletter; (iii) 
prepare  publications  and  reports  related  to  high-profile  CAREC  meetings  and  events;  (iv) 
prepare a summary of selected key reports and studies of CAREC for translation into Russian

12  Appendix 3  
and  Chinese;  and  (v)  help  arrange  for  media  coverage  of  high-profile  CAREC  meetings, 
projects, and activities, as required.
